speaker: C
text: What's up, guys? It's Ash Bennington. Welcome to Real Vision Crypto Daily briefing. Before I bring in our guests, I want to talk about an exciting initiative here at Real Vision. Michael, welcome to the show.

speaker: D
text: Hey, thanks so much. Great to be here, Michael, it's a.

speaker: C
text: Pleasure to have you. You and I were geeking out a little bit about traditional finance capital markets before the show started. You have a really interesting background. Tell us a little bit about your background and how you got into the crypto space.

speaker: D
text: Oh, gosh. You know, I'm from the west coast. I'm from San Francisco. And years ago, I used to be a lawyer, but before that, I studied kind of physical sciences at university. So I had kind of a mixed kind of, I had a legal mind to it, but I could also do some math, which is unusual for that profession, as it were.

speaker: C
text: Extremely unusual, as many of my lawyer.

speaker: D
text: Friends tell me, they always get the billables right, though, which is weird. I, but beyond that, not much math.

speaker: C
text: But great for doing math in six minute increments.

speaker: D
text: Yeah, exactly. They always know exactly what a 10th of an hour is. But, yeah, since then, I've done a number of things. I practiced law for a while. Then being in San Francisco, I ended up working at startups and really learned how to build a business, how to build technology and teams in a really effective but lightweight way. When I left the last company I was at, I had some time off. We did well, chilling, and one of my former colleagues said, hey, let's do something. And this is late 2017. And I said, great. Pitch me five ideas. And the stupidest one was in crypto. I said, let's do that one, because if that wins, that will win big. And if it's stupid, well, I do lots of stupid things, so that's fine. It turned out to work really well. So that's kind of how we got here.

speaker: C
text: So tell us, what was that so called stupid idea?

speaker: D
text: Oh, God. The original idea was doing a decentralized version of Moody's or s to rate icos because, you know, you really didn't think there was enough fundamentals in there and good analysis. It was all frothy. And so we thought we could create a fair game where you couldn't kind of game the system in terms of what your rating was in ICO. And it was a crazy idea, and it was never going to work. But lots of things that never were going to work were very successful back then. And as we did the research, we started looking at numbers on these decentralized exchanges. Like, back then, there was ether Delta or Bancor or Kyber, some of which are still around. And we looked at the markets and were like, wow, these are broken. The order books are crossing. Theres no automatic matching. Theres fat fingers every 10 seconds. Theres free money here. And so we started building these contracts that could do atomic swaps. On these exchanges in a very fast and very intelligent way. And that was a fun game for us, and that worked really well. So that's where we started. But come about 2018, when the ICO boom was cooling down, we thought need a more sophisticated way of trading. So we hired guys from places like jump and tower and built a more traditional HFT style shop. And that's what dexterity primarily is today.

speaker: C
text: Like any good Silicon Valley idea, it morphed and moved to where the market was and where the product market fit was. Talk a little bit about what you're doing at dexterity right now.

speaker: D
text: So our bread and butter is proprietary trading. We do low latency, high frequency trading of cryptocurrency assets, and our trades are market neutral. So we're indifferent to price. We're not riding waves up and down. We're looking for volatility, we're looking for volume, and that's what we're really good at. And so over the past maybe two or three years, we've traded a little over $2 trillion in crypto assets.

speaker: C
text: Yeah, these are huge numbers. So folks who have backgrounds in traditional capital markets, HFT, understand this model very well. But for folks who are coming to us native from the crypto space, who maybe have backgrounds in engineering or something related in the technology space, who don't understand the HFT model, talk a little bit about this and how it works.

speaker: D
text: Sure. I think crypto, unlike tradfi, is a bit unique. There's tons of venues trading the same assets, like every exchange has bitcoin, and theres lots of different pairs. You might get bitcoin margined in tether or USDC or formerly busD or other things like that, or in ether. You might even have a quanto situation where youre using some other cryptocurrency to margin your trades. What that means is that while youd like to think all the prices are the same across all venues, across all products at the same time, they just arent. And theres lots of nuances built into that. So what we look for is price dislocations and inefficiencies that that don't make sense, that are wrong, and then go so those prices up. And we have to do it very fast because these price differentials are very small. So you can't just do ten trades a day and make your p and l. You have to do 100,000 trades a day and just do that. You have to build some software that's very fast and very smart and plugs into all the exchanges in the optimal way so that you can capture those little price differences in your 100,000 trades to make a good p and l for the day. So that's the short of it.

speaker: C
text: Yeah. And to talk to folks on the opposite side of the spectrum, folks who've come to us from the traditional finance capital markets space, there's something, of course, that you're familiar with called Reg, NMS, NBBO, national best bid, best offer. Nothing like that exists in the crypto space. So you do get these dislocations. Let's talk a little bit about that framework, Michael. The dislocations, as you put it, the price deltas have narrowed pretty considerably over the last decade or so in crypto, but are still very high by traditional capital market standards. Talk a little bit about how great those price differentials are and also about the role that derivatives play versus the underlying in this game that you guys are playing.

speaker: D
text: Yeah, I mean, the market's pretty sophisticated now, so the price differentials are quite tight, as you said. If we're talking about back in 2018, you could see really some irrational price differentials, especially along the kind of long tail coins. So it's small and it gets smaller every year, I think. But that's kind of been our sweet spot in terms of figuring out how to work that. And the other unique thing about crypto, as you said, we've got weird derivatives products. We have a perpetual swap, which doesn't exist anywhere else, which is a future, or a swap that just does not settle. Instead, every 8 hours, somebody gets charged or paid a funding rate for being on one side of the swap price versus the perpetual swaps price. This is a hard thing to model because you have to guess how much you're going to get paid in 8 hours, depending on where you are now. And as that funding rate fluctuates over the 8 hours, you have to adjust your positions on both sides, because, like us, we're fully hedged, more market neutral. So this unique product has created a lot of interesting opportunities for people who like to nerd out on the maths behind all this stuff.

speaker: C
text: Yeah. So how do you guys go about. How do you guys go about that in terms of the team construction, in terms of the trading strategies, just in terms of the operational aspect of it? Because as you point out, it's a product that just does not exist in traditional capital markets.

speaker: D
text: Yeah. And happily, we tackled this back in 2018. And so we spent a lot of time and collected a lot of data trying to figure out how to model this perpetual swap, and we got quite good at it. And the backgrounds of people are what you'd expect. There are people from big tradfi trading shops who had done lots of different things. Some people did FX, some did oil and gas, some did commodities. But they have that kind of instinct for game theory. That's what they love. They love figuring out how the game works and cutting through it. So Kryptos is just a giant game theory experiment with a bunch of retail dj's thrown in. So it makes for a really exciting game to analyze because it's not always rational. But yeah, I think that's it. You need to find people who love solving really hard problems, who can't help but solve hard problems if you put one in front of them. If you ever heard the term nerd sniping, it's kind of, you know, you want to distract somebody, give them a question that's just hypothetical and useless, but really interesting mathematically, and they'll totally forget what they're doing to solve it. Those are the kind of people who win at this game.

speaker: C
text: So what's the landscape look like? Who are your competitors? Who are the counterparties? How does that work?

speaker: D
text: Yeah, so in terms of competitors, there's two major categories. There's the trad five guys who have come in primarily around 2019, 2020, and I of whom are now departed. And then youve got the crypto natives who are like us, who have built just for crypto because its kind of easier to get into crypto than tradfi building HfT and tradfi is a $10 million outlay just to get started in crypto. Its nothing. Its pretty much free because you dont need a lot of hardware. But back to your question. In terms of the competitors in tradfi, we saw the influx of guys like jump and Tower and Jane Street, Hudson river. These guys came in hard in the past few years and did really well. I think it was kind of interesting. So it was additive for us. They didn't eat our lunch, they made it so there was more lunch for everybody to eat. So it was a really good time having them in there. But as you've seen a lot of pullback over the past few months and that's been kind of a bummer all around. Yeah.

speaker: C
text: And how many of them have jumped out?

speaker: D
text: You know, I think in size, almost all of them, there might be one or two that are still lingering, but I think one shop I spoke to put it really well where they said, look, crypto is single digits of our revenue. In terms of percentages as a single digit percentage, but its 95% of my pr problem. And if youre a prop shop, you dont want a big pr department. You want to lay low and hang out and make money and have nobody know how. So these guys, they couldve kept doing it indefinitely. There was no reason for them to stop other than the bad pr did not outweigh kind of what was going on and how much revenue they were making from this business.

speaker: C
text: Hey, everyone, we're going to take a quick pause and hear a word from our partners. We'll be right back. Yeah, that makes perfect sense. I guess second best is to have nobody know how you make money. First best is to have nobody know you exist if you're a prop shop.

speaker: C
text: Yeah. So let's talk about the broader crypto landscape right now in terms of price action, in terms of what you guys are seeing. What's the overall 50,000 foot overview of how you would describe this market right now?

text: Volumes have created. This is like, this is like, it's like Christmas when nobody's trading because everyone's on holiday or something all the time. It's Christmas every day in a bad way.

text: So, Chris, Christmas every day in a bad way. I love that.

speaker: D
text: Yeah, yeah. You got to find a way to, you know, be negative about Christmas. I suppose. So. Anyways, it's, it's very, very quiet retail. That is, they've kind of pulled out because of all the regulatory stuff and all the bad press. And then you've got very high interest rates, which make it just less attractive to be in a high risk environment. So it's just very quiet. It's the best way to describe it.

speaker: C
text: Yeah. And what about the regulatory headwinds? How does that affect what you do.

speaker: D
text: As a prop shop? We're kind of, we don't have a super heavy duty regulatory burden. We're not trading other people's money. We're not hurting anybody. We're a fairly easier business to run in that way. And that's part of the reason we aren't a hedge fund. But we are keeping eyes on what's happening because it affects our counterparties and it affects the venues we're trading and what kind of assets we can trade. And it's interesting we've seen, I'm an ex lawyer, as I said, so I have a little bit of background in this. We've been watching the SEC fight in the courts, and it's just, it's not going the way they planned, I think. So I'm really uncertain how Congress is going to approach this over the next year. That ripple ruling maybe a month or two ago, that effectively said Ripple wasn't a security or didn't pass the Howie test when it was sold to retail on exchanges, because a blind order book, that was not something I've ever seen before or thought was plausible, and it's kind of turned the whole situation on its head. Yeah.

speaker: C
text: I think that ruling was especially confounding to us non lawyers because it seemed to suggest that institutional, institutional sales were problematic, whereas retail sales were not, which tends to be the exact sort of mirror image opposite of what you expect in terms of investor protections. But I guess Judge Annalisa Torres decision essentially was about the manner of sale rather than the underlying properties of the asset itself being a security or not being a security, which I think was kind of a curveball. As you said, no one expected it.

speaker: D
text: Yeah. And I think if that ruling stands, it leads to absurd outcomes where you can issue tokens willy nilly, so long as you don't sell them to institutions, and you only sell them kind of blindly on exchanges and via airdrops, which are free. So they're not sales and therefore don't meet the first prong of the Howey test. Well, you can make any token and say it's not security. So I think the SEC has to fight this and they have to get it overturned. Otherwise the world is stop security.

I know it gets confusing, but that's sort of how I think about it, at least.

You can have a distributed ledger anywhere and you don't need bitcoin for that. You just need the technology. And you want it to probably be interchangeable across different players in the spaces. I did watch the hamster races a few weeks ago. They were great, but they were not a life changing technology in Defi. But hey, people like to gamble on weird stuff.

speaker: C
text: It is so interesting when you mentioned this decoupling of decentralization blockchain technology from some of the coins that we see today, obviously, this is a very controversial statement. One of the things that decentralization has allowed is this decoupling of the nation state from the money supply in a way that was just simply not possible before, I guess, sort of absent some sort of a gold standard. And that's something that excites a lot of people in the space and that many people are very passionate about, particularly in the bitcoin community. But as you point out, whatever the sort of merits or attributes of that, it isn't necessarily intrinsic to the way that decentralization works. And I guess one of the major questions that I have, at least as I look across the space, is what happens when we do start getting CBDC, central bank digital currencies, or a treasury coin, in other words, something that's issued by either a nation state or a central bank. How does that impact the state that is, for me at least, probably the biggest single wildcard as we look out across this space today?

speaker: D
text: Yeah, I think the concept of them is really exciting. CBDCs and digital treasury treasuries and to a certain degree, real world asset tokens, those are all exciting things. But to the extent you have a centrally controlled CBDC, you can get coins blocked, you can get blacklists, and this is not something that kind of decentralized crypto purists like. So I do worry it's kind of the powers that be co opting our little revolution here of what money is and how it's managed. So while it'll be cool to have cash that's not physical, I don't think it's great for crypto. I think it's probably a net negative.

speaker: C
text: Yeah, I think that's very well said and very well framed. Let's shift gears here from the strategic to the more tactical. What's your outlook on the space for h 223, the second half of 2023?

text: I don't think there's a reason for things to get loud again. I think things will remain quiet. What I'm hoping for, though, is that things remain quiet in a good way. I'm hoping tether stands up just fine. And finance doesn't get destroyed.

text: Right?

speaker: D

speaker: D
text: We're doing a lot of what we used to do. Still, I won't lie, 2021 was such an amazing bull run. Things were frothy and crazy. We were not always as smart as we needed to be, or could have been, because we didn't need to be. Rather, we could not be capital efficient. And it was fine. We could choose kind of venues that we hadn't done full due diligence on. And it was fine because everything was going up. So we're still running the trades we always have run and they're still working. There's less volume to trade them against, but we figured out how to squeeze more revenue out of less volume. And we've seen some interesting opportunistic trades we wouldn't run otherwise because of the things that have been happening the past few months.

speaker: D
text: You know, this is the thing about high frequency trading. It's numbers in, numbers out. We collect data on all the coins that are being traded. We run analyses on this data, and then we decide what to trade. So whatever is the most liquid is literally whatever is the most liquid numerically. You can go to Coingecko or coinmarketcap and see what that is. It changes every week. Peppy got big. It became very liquid. We were on there, and probably within the first 48 hours we were trading FePI. After its launch, things tapered off. We don't trade it anymore. That's how we approach it, with just all numbers and numbers out.

text: Yeah, totally agnostic. You just don't care. Yep.

text: Well, real vision officially doesn't have a view about things where you just come and present ideas.
